choices.text: Primary ovarian insufficiency

questions.text:
A 32-year P3 comes to OPD with AUB. Menarche was at age 13 years, and she has had regular cycles till 1 year ago. She then began to have delayed periods every 45-60 days with heavy bleeding, clots but no cramping. She has not had her period in 4 months. She has no hot flushes, acne, or abnormal hair growth. She takes levo-thyroxine for hypothyroidism and has had a tubal ligation done. Height is 160 cm, weight is 120kg. P/S is normal. Bimanual exam is limited by body habitus. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Lab tests are as follows:

TSH- 2.9, Prolactin: 16, LH: 15

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anovulation

Explanation

  • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because
    • She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels.
    • This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels.
    •  This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)

Other Options:

  • This is not primary ovarian insufficiency as there are no hot flushes which mean estrogen levels are normal/ high
  • Her TSH levels are normal so this is not hypothyroidism
  • Leiomyoma presents as heavy bleeding in regular cycles.

Educational Objective:

  • Anovular cycles are common in women with high BMI

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Large submucosal fibroid
Simple endometrial hyperplasia
Nulliparous woman

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Large submucosal fibroid

 

Explanation: 

 

  • This is an image of an intra-uterine device
  • Contra-indications to Intrauterine Devices include
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperal Sepsis
  • Septic Abortion
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Cervical cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Distorted uterine cavity (Pre-existing uterine fibroids that distort the uterine cavity may be incompatible with insertion and proper placement of the IUD)
  • PID

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis, a condition where the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) breaks through the muscle wall of the uterus, is not a contraindication for IUD use, it  helps in reducing the heavy menstrual bleeding associated with adenomyosis.

 

Option B. Large Submucosal Fibroid (Correct Answer): A large submucosal fibroid, which protrudes into the uterine cavity, can distort the uterine cavity and interfere with the proper placement and function of an IUD. This can increase the risk of expulsion, malposition, or even perforation, making it a contraindication for IUD use.

 

Option C. Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia: Simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is generally not a contraindication for IUD use. In fact, hormonal IUDs that release progestin can be part of the treatment plan for endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Nulliparous Woman: While historically there was hesitation in using IUDs in nulliparous women, current evidence supports the safety and efficacy of IUDs in this population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large submucosal fibroids that distort the uterine cavity are a contraindication for IUD use due to the potential for complications such as expulsion or perforation. Other conditions like adenomyosis, simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, or being a nulliparous woman are not contraindications for IUD use.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition page 109

72 days

questions.text: The Anti-progesterone compound RU-486 is effective for inducing abortion if the duration of pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 63 days

Explanation:

  • RU-486 is Mifepristone and along with Misoprostol, it is used for medical methods of abortion.
  • A combi pack of mifepristone and misoprostol (one tablet of mifepristone 200mg and four tablets of misoprostol 200mcg each) has been approved by the Central Drugs Standard Control Organization, Directorate General of Health Services, for the medical termination of pregnancy up to n ee9ks (63 days) LMP in December 2008
  • However; CAC Training & Service Delivery Guidelines, 2016 by MoHFW, GoI recommends its use up to 49 days (7 weeks) in public sector sites, in line with the MTP Rules 2003.
  • A proposed amendment to the MTP Act, 1971, to increase the gestation limit for MMA to 9 weeks in public sector sites is under process. Till the proposal is approved, MMA in public health facility would be allowed only up to 7 weeks.
  • So if the question asks approved for use in public health facility, the answer will be 49 days, but it can be given till 9 weeks of pregnancy

Other Options: 

  • Option B, C and D all have duration > 63 days. Betwen 9 - 12 weeks, suction evacuation is preferred. After 12 weeks, a medical abortion is again preferred (i.e. different regimes of mifepristone f/b misoprostol have been described). 

Educational Objective: 

  • A combi pack of mifepristone and misoprostol (one tablet of mifepristone 200mg and four tablets of misoprostol 200mcg each) has been approved by the Central Drugs Standard Control Organization, Directorate General of Health Services, for the medical termination of pregnancy up to n ee9ks (63 days) LMP in December 2008
  • However; CAC Training & Service Delivery Guidelines, 2016 by MoHFW, GoI recommends its use up to 49 days (7 weeks) in public sector sites, in line with the MTP Rules 2003.

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/MMA_Handbook.pdf

questions.text: As per the 2021 amendment of the MTP act, the upper limit of gestational age for terminating a fetus with substantial anomalies is:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. No upper limit

 

Explanation:

Very Important 

As per the 2021 MTP amendment: act, a few important changes which you have to know are that the upper limit of gestational age has been increased  as per the following: 

  •  Till 20 weeks for original indications (maternal indication, fetal indication, failure of contraception and rape); opinion of 1 RMP required
  • Till 24 weeks for select indications like fetal maformation, rape, humanitarian grounds and maternal diability; opinion of 2 RMPS required
  • After 24 weeks: Only for substantial fetal malformations (No upper limit but this has to be allowed by a medical board)

Educational Objective:

  • Till 24 weeks for select indications like fetal maformation, rape, humanitarian grounds and maternal diability; opinion of 2 RMPS required

choices.text: The patient has stage IIIb disease
No further treatment required as lymphadenectomy already done
Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer helps in staging and guiding further management
The patient will require adjuvant vaginal brachytherappy

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent hysterectomy with bilateral salpingooophorectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy for endometrial cancer. Histopathology confirms lymph node involvement.  Which of the following statements is correct:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer helps in staging and guiding further management

  • The patient has stage IIIc disease as per FIGO staging and  she will require complete surgical resection (TAH + BSO with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy) followed by post operative adjuvant EBRT +/- chemotherapy
  • Lymphadenectomy is required for accurate staging and is considered a staging procedure. Its potential therapeutic benefits are mainly contribution to accurate indication for adjuvant therapy.
  • Most patients presenting with Stage III endometrial cancer are managed by complete surgical resection of all pelvic and/or nodal disease, followed by postoperative EBRT and/or chemotherapy.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: The patient has stage IIIb disease: involvement of pelvic and para-aortic lymoh node involvement means stage III-C
  • Option B: No further treatment required as lymphadenectomy already done: Treatment of endocmtrial canncer is surgery f/b radiotherapy or chemotherapy. Only in very early stages with log grade tumor (Stage 1A1) is surgery sufficient
  • Option D: The patient will require adjuvant vaginal brachytherappy: Folowing surgery for endomatrial cancer, radiotherapy is given as external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) and not brachytherapy

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Figo cancer report 2021

questions.text: Which of the following arrows depicts where the uterosacral ligament is ligated during a type II radical hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. B

 

Explanation

 

Types of Hysterectomy

 

  • In this image, they have shown the utero-sacral ligaments and have asked about a type 2 hysterectomy; hence midway is the best answer

Educational Objective:

  • In a type 2 radical hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are ligated at the level of the ureter and the uterosacral ligaments are divided midway between the uterus and the sacrum
  • In a type 3 hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are ligated at the origin of the internal iliac vessels and the uterosacral ligaments are ligated near the sacrum

 

 

Ref: Page 171, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: Persistence of endometriosis is directly dependent on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Estrogen

Explanation

Endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic state

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state.
  • Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands.
  • Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue.
  • The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.

Ref: Page no 233, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

 

  • The obstetric conjugate is the shortest antero-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet and measures 10 cm.

 

Other options

 

  • Option A: True conjugate: True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Option C: Anatomical conjugate: This is another name for the true conjugate: Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It measures 11 cm.
  • Option D: Bispinous diameter (10 cms) is the transverse diameter of the mid-pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet

 

Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter

 

  • True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
  • Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.

 

Transverse Diameter (13 cm)

 

  • Distance between the farthest two points on the iliopectineal line.
  • It is the largest diameter of pelvic inlet

 

Oblique Diameters (12 cm)

 

  • Right oblique diameter: Passes from right sacroiliac joint to left ilio-pubiceminence
  • Left oblique diameter: Passes from left sacroiliac joint to right ilio-pubic eminence

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: She will not respond favorably to induction of labor and will require pre-induction cervical ripening
She will not respond favorably to induction and LSCS should be done
She will respond favorably to induction of labor
The given information is insufficient to make a conclusion

questions.text: A 32-year G2 presents to the antenatal OPD. Her period of gestation is 40 weeks. She is planned for induction of labor. On a vaginal exam, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, 1 cm long, soft inconsistency and mid-position. The station of the fetal head is at -1. She asks if induction of labor will be successful? What will you tell her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. She will respond favorably to induction of labor

 

  • Bishop’s score is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • In this patient, the Bishop score is 8 (As seen from the Bishop score below)
  • A Bishop score > 6 is favourable i.e. she will respond favorably to induction of labor

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bishop score is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

 

 

Ref: Page no 247, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: Mrs. Shiny, a G2P1L1 presented to the hospital in labor pains. On examination she had 3 uterine contractions of 20 seconds in 10 minutes, Cervical dilation was 6 cm and HR 145 bpm. What is the stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stage I

 

Stages 1 of labor is from the onset of true labor pains to full dilatation of the cervix.

 

Other Options

 

  • Stage 2 of labor is from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the baby
  • Stage 3 of labor is from delivery of the baby to delivery of the placenta
  • Stage 4 of labor is from delivery of the placenta to an hour of observation post delivery

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal Labor

 

Uterine contractions which bring about cervical effacement and dilatation.

 

Stage 1:

 

  • From 0 cm to 10 cm dilatation
  • Divided into latent phase and active phase.
  • Latent phase: The point at which mother perceives regular contractions.
  • Active phase: Cervical dilatation of
    • 4cm (as per the WHO modified partograph)
    • 5 cm (As per the new WHO labor care guide)
    • 6 cm (As per ACOG).

 

Stage 2:

 

  • Complete cervical dilatation with active expulsive efforts by the mother

 

Stage 3:

 

  • Delivery of placenta and membranes

 

Stage 4:

 

  • “The Golden hour”
  • One hour after delivery of baby. The mother should be monitored for signs of post-partum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 227, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Reposit the hand back and external version
Reposit the hand back and internal version

questions.text: A 32yr G2P1 is referred at her 36 weeks from the primary health center with prolonged labor. On examination, the patient is dehydrated. Abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus which is tonically contracted. The presentation is unclear. Fetal heart rate is absent. On local examination, the hand is seen outside the introitus. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cesarean section

 

  • This is a case of hand prolapse with neglected shoulder presentation.
  • The patient is in obstructed labor
  • The best management option is an emergency LSCS (even for a dead fetus)
  • Post LSCS, the catheter should be kept for a minimum of 2 weeks to allow bladder healing and prevent VVF formation

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: All are risk factors for shoulder dystocia except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Primigravida

 

Primigravid women are NOT at a higher risk for hsoulder dystocia

 

Let's Discuss the other Options:

 

  • Option A: Previous h/o shoulder dystocia: This increases the risk of a repeat shoulder dystocia
  • Option B: Multiparity: Multiparous women are at a higher risk of shoulder dystocia. This could be as the weight of the fetus tends to increase with every pregnancy
  • Option D: Vacuum delivery: This also increases the risk of shoulder dytocia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Risk factors for shoulder dystocia include

 

  1. Previous shoulder dystocia
  2. Macrosomia
  3. Diabetes
  4. Obesity
  5. Induced labor
  6. Prolonged labor
  7. Vacuum and forceps (more common with vacuum)
  8. Anencephaly
  9. Multiparity
  10. Post maturity

 

ReF: Page no 469, DC Duttas textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy, has an uneventful vaginal delivery of a full-term infant. One day postpartum, she complains of visual changes and a severe headache. Two hours after this, she is found unresponsive and profoundly hypotensive. She is intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. Her BP is 68/28 mmHg. Heart rate is 140 bp. O2 saturation is 95% on FiO2 of 0.40. Physical exam is unremarkable. Lab tests are notable for glucose of 48 mg/ dl with a normal hematocrit and TLC. Which of the following will reverse her hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrocortisone

 

  • This patient has evidence of Sheehan syndrome after giving birth.
  • In this syndrome, the postpartum hypoplastic pituitary is at increased risk for hemorrhage and/or infarction. This leads to bilateral visual changes, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • In severe cases, cardiovascular collapse and altered levels of consciousness may be observed.
  • Laboratory evaluation commonly shows hypoglycemia.
  • Pituitary computed tomography (CT) or MRI may show signs of sellar hemorrhage if present. Involvement of all pituitary hormones may be seen, although the most acute findings are often hypoglycemia and hypotension from failure of ACTH.
  • The hypoglycemia and hypotension present in this patient suggest failure of the glucocorticoid system; thus, treatment with a corticosteroid is indicated. There is no evidence of sepsis; thus, antibiotics and drotrecogin alfa are not indicated. With a normal hematocrit and no reported evidence of massive hemorrhage, packed red cell transfusion is unlikely to be helpful. Although TSH production is undoubtedly low in this patient, the most immediate concern is replacement of glucocorticoid

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3183525/

choices.text: Rotation of the neck
Rotation of the shoulders
Untwisting of the neck
Untwisting of the shoulders

questions.text: External rotation occurs after the head is born. The head moves by 45and this occurs because?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rotation of the shoulders

 

  • Once the head is born by extension, it is now free from the confines of the pelvis and untwists by 45 This untwisting of the neck is called as restitution.
  • Now the shoulders undergo internal rotation by 45 When the shoulders turn, the head automatically turns and this is visible as external rotation.
  • So external rotation is nothing but internal rotation of the shoulders

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cardinal movement of external rotation is actually internal rotation of the shoulders

 

Ref: Page no 224, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: A 23y woman has a suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. The HPE is reported as a partial mole. You counsel her that her risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-5%

Educational Objective: 

  • Risk of progress of complete mole to GTN: 15-20 %
  • Risk of progress of partial mole to GTN: 1-5%

questions.text: A raised uterine pulsatility index at 11-14 weeks on uterine artery doppler is a predictor for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine artery blood flow is estimated to rise from 50ml/min early in gestation to 500-700 ml/ min by term
  • Doppler waveform of the uterine artery shows high diastolic flow velocity and markedly turbulent flow.
  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Thus, option D) Pre-eclampsia is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A raised uterine PI is not related to gestational diabetes, Down syndrome or placenta previa

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching  on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Ref: Page no 214, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Lithium in pregnancy is associated with an increased incidence of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ebstein anomaly

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

Ref: Page no 245, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Mifepristone + Misoprostol
Conservative management

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of 3 months pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is palpable. An ultrasound shows the following picture. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Suction & Evacuation

  • This image shows the typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’
  • This seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • The treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction evacuation followed by beta hCG surveillance

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for 1st trimester MTPs or missed abortions but not for molar pregnancy
  • Option B: Conservative management will not help as the molar tissue has to be evacuated
  • Option D: Hysterotomy is NOT indicated for a molar pregnancy, even for larger gestational ages, a suction evacuation is done

Educational Objective: 

Treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation followed by beta hCG surveilance

 

Ref: Page no. 391, 392 William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Early intra-uterine pregnancy
Intra-uterine pseudo gestational sac
Tubal ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: Double Decidual Sac sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Early Intra – uterine pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Double decidual sac sign is seen in an intra-uterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: An intra-uterine pseudo sac is seen usually in an ectopic pregnancy, It is fluid collection in the uterus
  • Option C: Tubal ectopic pregnancy: in this a double decidual sac sign wont be seen. USG signs of a tubal pregnancy include bagel sign, blob sign and ring of fire sign
  • Option D: In Molar pregnancy, the characteristic sign seen is the snowstorm appearance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Double Decidual sac sign:

 

  • Is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy (IUP) 
  • Especially useful when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualized.
  • It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac)
  • It is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.
  • Where the two adhere is the decidua basalis, and is the site of future placental formation.

 

 

Another sign of an intra-uterine pregnancy is the intra-decidual sign.

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics

choices.text: Associated with hematometra and hamatocolpos
Cyclic pelvic pain is experienced
Breast development is absent/ delayed
Cruciate incision will relieve symptoms

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to OPD and the below examination finding is seen. Which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Breast development is absent/ delayed

 

  • The finding here is that of an imperforate hymen
  • In this there is obstructed outflow to menstrual blood which accumulates in the vagina (hematocolpos) and in the uterus (hematometra) and presents as primary amenorrhoea with presence of secondary sexual characters (as the HPO axis is normal) with a bluish bulge at the introitus.

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Associated with Hematometra and Hematocolpos. An imperforate hymen can lead to the hematocolpos and hematometra due to the obstruction of menstrual flow.

 

Option B. Cyclic Pelvic Pain is Experienced: The accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina and uterus often causes cyclic pelvic pain, which coincides with menstrual cycles , known as cryptomenorrhea.

 

Option C. Breast Development is Absent/Delayed: Least likely. In cases of imperforate hymen, the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is intact, and normal secondary sexual characteristics, including breast development, are usually present

 

Option D. Cruciate Incision will Relieve Symptoms: A cruciate incision of the hymen is a common surgical intervention to relieve symptoms by allowing the accumulated menstrual blood to drain, thus relieving pain and pressure.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of imperforate hymen, patients typically present with symptoms like primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, and a bulging hymen due to the accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina and uterus (hematocolpos and hematometra). These individuals usually have normal secondary sexual development since the hormonal axis is intact. Surgical intervention, such as a cruciate incision of the hymen, is effective in relieving these symptoms.

 

Ref: Speroff’s 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to OPD with primary amenorrhea. Her height is 135 cm. She has a webbed neck and increased carrying angle. Breast development is tanner 1 with widely spaced nipple, external genitalia are infantile. The Karyotype is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 45 X0

 

  • This is a case of Turner syndrome.
  • Short stature, widely spaced nipple, short fourth metacarpals, increased carrying angle are typical features of Turner syndrome.
  • Karyotype is 45X0.
  • Mosaics of 45X0/46XX or 45 X0/46XY may exist.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: Normal female karyotype.

 

Option B. 46 XY: Normal male karyotype.

 

Option D. 47 XXY: This karyotype is associated with Klinefelter syndrome, which is characterized by a male phenotype with some level of hypogonadism and gynecomastia, not matching the clinical presentation described in the girl.

 

Educational Objective: In a patient presenting with primary amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and infantile external genitalia, the karyotype most likely to be found is 45 X0, indicative of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is characterized by the absence of all or part of a second sex chromosome, leading to various developmental and physical abnormalities. Identification of this condition is crucial for appropriate management and support.

 

Ref: Speroff’s 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of secondary amenorrhea. On examination, there is galactorrhoea, and her prolactin levels are high. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is treatment of choice for her:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cabergoline

 

  • This is a scenario of hyperprolactinemia which commonly presents as galactorrhoea and oligomenorrhoea (Delayed cycles)
  • Dopamine agonists are the first line treatment for hyperprolactinemia. Bromocriptine and cabergoline are first line treatments.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option. A. Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCP): OCPs are used to regulate menstrual cycles and provide contraception

 

Option. C. Dexamethasone: is a steroid used in the treatment of various conditions, including some endocrine disorders, but it is not a first-line treatment for hyperprolactinemia.

 

Option. D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a hormone that stimulates uterine contractions and milk ejection in lactation

 

Educational Objective: The treatment of choice for hyperprolactinemia, which often presents with galactorrhoea and secondary amenorrhea, is dopamine agonists such as cabergoline or bromocriptine. These medications effectively lower prolactin levels, which can help restore normal menstrual function and resolve galactorrhoea

 

Ref:  Speroff’s 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: A curious pregnant patient visits the antenatal OPD. She has missed her period by 4 days and her pregnancy test is positive. This is her 1st pregnancy and although, sex detection is banned in India, she is very curious about how the baby forms and asks if it is possible to know the sex of the baby now. You tell her that the gonads are undifferentiated at present. The gonads are bipotent till?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • The gonads are BIPOTENT (Undifferentiated) till 5 weeks, they then differentiate into testes or ovaries based on whether the karyotype is 46XX or 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

  • This is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp
  • It is applied at the level of the uterine arteries  (level of internal os) during abdominal myomectomy to reduce the intra-operative blood loss by occluding the uterine arteries temporarily

questions.text: A 30 y comes to OPD for evaluation of absent periods. The patient had a vaginal delivery 8 months ago and shes not had her period since delivery. Her postpartum course was complicated by atonic PPH requiring massive blood transfusion. At a visit, 2 months ago, the patient was started on combined OCPs, and she has not had vaginal bleeding. Prior to this pregnancy she had regular monthly cycles. She also has increased fatigue. She is not lactating and is bottle feeding her baby. There is no headache, galactorrhoea, or hot flushes. BMI is 31, vitals are normal. Pelvic examination shows clear vaginal discharge and well rugate vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted. UPT is negative. TSH levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sheehan Syndrome

 

Etiopathogenesis:

 

  • During pregnancy, the pituitary gland enlarges due to hyperplasia of lactotrophs.
  • In the setting of severe blood loss or hypotension during/after delivery, the enlarged pituitary is vulnerable to ischemia.
  • Leads to necrosis of pituitary tissue, resulting in partial or complete hypopituitarism.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Early signs:
    • Failure to lactate (due to prolactin)
    • Prolonged amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea
    • Fatigue, hypotension
  • Late signs:
    • Loss of secondary sexual hair (pubic/axillary)
    • Cold intolerance, dry skin ( TSH)
    • Hypoglycemia, weight loss ( ACTH, cortisol)
    • Infertility

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • History of severe PPH with failure to resume normal postpartum function
  • Hormonal assays: levels of prolactin, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, GH
  • MRI of pituitary may show an empty sella or hypoplastic gland

 

Treatment:

 

  • Lifelong hormone replacement therapy, including:
    • Glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone)
    • Levothyroxine
    • Estrogen/progesterone (if fertility not desired)
    • Gonadotropins (if fertility desired)

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. Asherman syndrome: Asherman syndrome is a condition characterized by intrauterine adhesions or synechiae, often resulting from trauma to the endometrium, typically after dilation and curettage. It leads to menstrual abnormalities (amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea), infertility, and recurrent pregnancy loss. Diagnosis is confirmed by hysteroscopy, and treatment involves surgical adhesiolysis.

 

Option. C. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is an endocrine disorder characterized by irregular menstrual cycles, signs of hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries. While the patient has an elevated BMI, a common feature in PCOS, the absence of her periods following a complicated postpartum course and the absence of typical PCOS symptoms make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option. D. Primary Ovarian Insufficiency: Primary ovarian insufficiency, also known as premature ovarian failure, involves early depletion of ovarian follicles and usually presents with elevated FSH levels, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Asherman syndrome, characterized by intrauterine adhesions or scarring typically following uterine surgery or trauma, is the most likely cause of secondary amenorrhea in a patient with a history of postpartum hemorrhage and D&C. The diagnosis is supported by the absence of menstrual bleeding even with hormonal stimulation and a history suggestive of intrauterine injury.

 

  • Asherman syndrome is intra uterine adhesions, they arise due to:
    • Surgical trauma to the uterus which may be seen following
      • Dilatation and curettage (esp. sharp curettage)
      • Cesarean section
      • Myomectomy where the endometrial cavity is involved
      • Metroplasty
      • Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Endometrial ablative procedures
    • Intra-uterine infections like tuberculosis and schistosomiasis
  • Symptoms:
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • Diagnosis
    • On ultrasound
  • Uterine cavity appears irregular/ interrupted; punctate echogenic foci in the endometrium/ indistinct endo-myometrial junction/ endometrial fluid: commonly loculated appearing as small focal cystic areas within the endometrium
  • On HSG
    • Intra-uterine filling defects are seen giving a moth-eaten appearance
  • Hysteroscopy
    • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis
    • Post procedure:
      •  To stimulate endometrial proliferation and prevent reformation of adhesions, oral estrogen administration has proved effective. A cooper containing intra-uterine device can also be inserted to prevent reformation of adhesions
      • Another hysteroscopy or HSG is typically performed at 3 months following the initial resection.

 

Ref: Speroffs 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: Preeti, a 20-year-old girl presents with a history of rapidly developing hirsutism, severe acne and amenorrhea. Her BMI is 19. To establish the diagnosis, which would be the most appropriate blood test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Testosterone

 

For cases of virilisation and hirsutism, serum testosterone is the investigation of choice

 

  • A variety of ovarian neoplasms, both benign and malignant may produce testosterone and lead to virilization. Specifically, women with an abrupt onset, typically within several months, or sudden worsening of virilizing signs should prompt concern for a hormone producing ovarian or adrenal tumour.

  • Symptoms may include deepening of voice, frontal balding, severe acne, or hirsutism or both, increased muscle mass and clitoromegaly.

  • Accordingly, serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumours. Free testosterone levels are more sensitive than total testosterone levels as an indicator of hyperandrogenism.

  • "Threshold values beyond 200 ng/dl of total testosterone warrant evaluation for an ovarian lesion".

  • Testosterone estimation is the best investigation in case of rapid onset hirsutism and amenorrhea.

  • M/C cause of rapid onset hirsutism in young females = Testosterone producing tumour

  • DHEA sulphate is produced exclusively by the adrenal gland. Therefore, serum DHEAS levels above 700 mcg/dl are highly sensitive for the presence of an adrenal neoplasm.

  • Adrenal imaging with abdominal CT or MRI is indicated for any patient with DHEAS levels that exceed this value.

 

Let us look at each option separately:

 

Option. A. 17-OH Progesterone: This test is used to evaluate adrenal gland function and diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a condition that can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities. However, the rapid onset of symptoms described is less typical for CAH.

 

Option. B. DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone): DHEA is an androgen produced by the adrenal glands. While elevated levels can contribute to hirsutism and acne, DHEA alone may not provide a definitive diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Testosterone: Correct. Elevated levels of testosterone are a key indicator of hyperandrogenism, which can manifest as hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities. Measuring testosterone levels is crucial in diagnosing conditions like PCOS or androgen-secreting tumors, which can present with rapid onset of symptoms.

 

Option. D. LH: FSH Ratio: This ratio is often evaluated in the diagnosis of PCOS, as women with PCOS may have an elevated ratio. However, a normal ratio does not rule out PCOS, and it is not as directly indicative of hyperandrogenism as elevated testosterone levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When evaluating a young woman with rapid onset of hirsutism, severe acne, and amenorrhea, measuring serum testosterone levels is crucial for diagnosing conditions associated with hyperandrogenism, such as PCOS or androgen-secreting tumors.

 

Ref: Page 449, Speroffs clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: The most common degeneration seen in uterine fibroids is
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyaline degeneration

Explanation

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Red degeneration, calcific degeneration and fatty degeneration are other kinds of degeneration in fibroids 

Educational Objective:

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Ref: Page no 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology

questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation

  • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.
  • On examination, this is  a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids)
    • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular
    • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)
    • The woman is nulliparous

Other Options:

  • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size)
  • In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding
  • In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

Educational Objective: 

C/f of fibroid uterus

Symptoms

  • Menorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Abdominal mass and pressure symptoms

Signs:

  • Uterus regularly enlarged (single fibroid) or irregularly enlarged (multiple fibroids)
  • Transmitted mobility is felt in a fibroid 

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman presents to OPD with painful menstruation. On examination, normal secondary sexual characters are present. The vagina is patent but shows a bulge on the right side near the cervix. On per rectal examination, there is a bulge felt about 4 cm from anal verge and is more towards left side. On Ultrasound, there is hematocolpos and the left side kidney is absent. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. OHVIRA syndrome

 

  • Options A. OHVIRA: obstructed hemi vagina and ipsilateral renal agenesis is a syndrome characterized by uterus didelphys, unilateral vaginal obstruction, and ipsilateral renal agenesis. The patient has normal menses from one hemi uterus and features of cyclic pelvic pain and hematocolpos on side of obstructed hemivagina.

 

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: MRKH syndrome can have absent kidney / renal and skeletal abnormalities but usually does not have hematocolpos
  • Option C: ACUM is an accessory and cavitated uterine horn. Patients present with dysmenorrhea and features similar to endometriosis.
  • Option D: Robert uterus is a rare uterine anomaly with asymmetrical uterine septum resulting in obstructed hemi cavity resulting in hematometra on one side. Patient has normal menses with dysmenorrhea. No bulge in vagina will be felt. On per rectal examination, the bulge may not be palpable as mostly hematometra and hematosalpinx is more likely and there is no hematocolpos.

 

Educational Objective: OHVIRA syndrome is characterized by a uterine anomaly such as uterine didelphys with obstructed hemivagina leading to hematocolpos, often accompanied by ipsilateral renal agenesis. This syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with painful menstruation, a unilateral vaginal bulge, and corresponding renal anomalies on imaging. Diagnosis and management of OHVIRA syndrome are crucial for alleviating symptoms and addressing potential reproductive complications.

 

Ref: Speroff’s 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

choices.text: Elevated liver enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of HELLP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Retroplacental hemorrhage 

 

HELLP Syndrome

 

  • It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm3
  • It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension.
  • It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Manifested by nausea, vomiting, epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, along with biochemical and hematological changes.
  • Parenchymal necrosis of liver causes elevation in hepatic enzymes (AST and ALT > 70 IU/L and LDH > 600 IU/L).
  • There may be subcapsular hematoma formation (which may need CT scanning) and abnormal peripheral smear.
  • Eventually liver may rupture to cause sudden hypotension, due to hemoperitoneum.

 

Let's evaluate each option to identify the one that is not a part of HELLP syndrome:

 

Option A. Hemolysis: Hemolysis refers to the breakdown of red blood cells, which is a key feature of HELLP syndrome.

 

Option B. Elevated Liver Enzymes: Elevated liver enzymes indicate liver dysfunction, which is another essential component of HELLP syndrome.

 

Option C. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia is a significant reduction in platelet count, which is the third critical component of HELLP syndrome

 

Option D. Retroplacental Hemorrhage: This is the correct answer. Retroplacental haemorrhage, also known as placental abruption, is a separate obstetric complication that involves the detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. While it can be a serious condition, it is not a part of HELLP syndrome.

 

Educational Objective

 

HELLP Syndrome

 

  • It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm3
  • It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension.
  • It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria

 

Ref: Page no 1849, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Pre-gestational diabetes
Gestational diabetes mellitus
Effect of valproate
Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pre-gestational diabetes

 

  • This image is mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia
  • It is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Let's examine each of the options:

 

  1. Pre-gestational Diabetes: This refers to diabetes that exists before pregnancy. Women with pre-gestational diabetes have a higher risk of giving birth to babies with congenital anomalies, including neural tube defects and cardiovascular malformations.
     
  2. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM): This type of diabetes develops during pregnancy and generally resolves after delivery. While GDM can lead to several complications, such as macrosomia or hypoglycemia in the baby, it is not typically associated with congenital anomalies.
     
  3. Effect of Valproate: Valproate use during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, is associated with an increased risk of several congenital malformations, including neural tube defects, cleft palate, and heart defects.
     
  4. Hypertensive on ACE Inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are not recommended during pregnancy, as they can lead to fetal complications such as renal damage. However, there is no known association between the use of ACE inhibitors and sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with pre-gestational diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Ref: Page 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Hep-B Vaccine should be administered within 24 hours of birth
HBIG should be administered within 12 hours of birth.

questions.text: A 30y primigravida presents in labor at 38 weeks. The resident notes that she is HBsAg positive. Which of the following statements regarding immunization of a newborn born to a HBsAg positive mother is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hep-B Vaccine and HBIG should be administered within 12 hours of birth)

 

Newborn of HBSAg positive mothers: The following has to be given to reduce the risk of Hepatitis B in the neonate

 

  • Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) 0.5 ml IM (intramuscular) within 12 hours of birth
  • Active immunization with Hep B vaccine (0.5 ml) IM at a separate site at birth.
  • Passive + Active immunization: 85 95% effective in preventing transmission.
  • Breastfeeding is not contra-indicated.

 

 

Vaccination schedule of hepatitis B vaccine 

 

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition Page 1065

choices.text: Stop Telmisartan 3 months prior to conception and re-start it at the 3rd month of pregnancy
Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol
Continue Telmisartan and add Labetalol if BP is uncontrolled in pregnancy

questions.text: A 37-year lady with chronic hypertension visits the gynecologist for pre-conceptional counselling. She is currently taking Telmisartan for her hypertension. Which is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol

 

  • Preconceptionally, women who are chronic HTN need to be
  • Assesses for ventricular hypertrophy, retinopathy and renal disease
  • Discuss medicine teratogenicity (ACE-I, ARBs, diuretics and beta blockers are contra-indicated in pregnancy)
  • Optimize BP control
  • Switch to an agent appropriate for pregnancy (labetalol, calcium channel blockers)
  • ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are not formed.

 

Let's assess each statement regarding Telmisartan:

 

Option A. Stop Telmisartan 3 months prior to conception and re-start it at the 3rd month of pregnancy: This advice is incorrect. Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) and is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of causing fetal harm. It should not be restarted during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol: This is the correct answer. ARBs like Telmisartan are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other complications. Labetalol is a safer alternative for managing hypertension in women who are planning to conceive and during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue Telmisartan: Incorrect. ARBs are contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential fetal risks.

 

Option D. Continue Telmisartan and add Labetalol if BP is uncontrolled in pregnancy: Incorrect. Telmisartan should not be used during pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are nor formed and are therefore contra-indicated in pregnancy.  

 

Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

questions.text: All of the following indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia in a pregnant female of chronic hypertension except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

 

 

Let's assess each option to determine which one does not indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia:

 

Option A. New Onset Proteinuria: The development of new-onset proteinuria in a pregnant woman with chronic hypertension can be a sign of superimposed pre-eclampsia. It is one of the criteria for diagnosing this condition.

 

Option B. Platelet Count < 75,000: A significant drop in platelet count, known as thrombocytopenia, can be an indication of superimposed pre-eclampsia. It is a concerning feature associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Increase in Systolic BP by 30 mm Hg and Diastolic by 15 mm Hg: This is the correct answer. An increase in systolic blood pressure by 30 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure by 15 mm Hg from baseline may indicate worsening hypertension in a pregnant woman but does not specifically indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia. Instead, it suggests poorly controlled chronic hypertension or exacerbation of hypertension.

 

Option D. Fresh Retinal Hypertensive Changes: The presence of fresh retinal hypertensive changes is a concerning sign and may indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia is made when a woman with chronic essential hypertension develops any of the above maternal organ dysfunction consistent with preeclampsia. Rises in BP per se are not sufficient to diagnose superimposed preeclampsia, as such rises are difficult to distinguish from the usual increase in BP after 20 weeks gestation. In the absence of preexisting proteinuria, new-onset proteinuria in the setting of a rise in BP is sufficient to diagnose superimposed preeclampsia.

 

 

Ref: Page no 1780, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Consider termination of pregnancy
Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
IV Acyclovir
Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG)

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1L1 teacher presents at 22 weeks with fever and rash since 2 days. She gives history of contact with a child in her class who had chicken pox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration

Chickenpox in Pregnancy

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

questions.text: A 25-year-old P2L2 had just delivered following induction for severe preeclampsia. Her BP on the 2nd postnatal day is 160/100mmHg. Which anti-hypertensive should be avoided in a breastfeeding mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amlodipine

 

  • Antihypertensive agents with no known adverse effects on infants receiving breast milk: Mnemonic: ECLAM-N
    • Enalapril
    • Captopril
    • Labetalol
    • Atenolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Nifedipine
  • Antihypertensive agents with insufficient evidence on infant safety in breast-feeding (not recommended in breast feeding mothers):
    • Angiotensin receptor blocking agents
    • Amlodipine
    • ACE-Inhibitors (Except enalapril and captopril)

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is generally not the preferred choice in breastfeeding mothers. This is the correct answer. Given the limited data and the existence of safer alternatives, amlodipine is often avoided or used with caution in breastfeeding mothers.

 

Option B. Labetalol: Labetalol, a beta-blocker, is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers. It does not significantly pass into breast milk and is commonly used for managing hypertension in postpartum women.

 

Option C. Captopril: Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is generally considered safe in breastfeeding mothers. Captopril can be used for managing hypertension in a breastfeeding mother, though close monitoring is recommended.

 

Option D. Nifedipine: Nifedipine, another calcium channel blocker, is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers. It is excreted into breast milk in small amounts and is commonly used in postpartum hypertension.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Antihypertensive agents with no known adverse effects on infants receiving breast milk: Mnemonic: ECLAM-N
    • Enalapril
    • Captopril
    • Labetalol
    • Atenolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Nifedipine

 

Ref: Smith, M , Waugh, J, NelsonPiercy, C Management of postpartum hypertension The Obstetrician & Gynecologist 2013; 15: 45 50

questions.text: A 28 y G2P1 presents to the OPD with a missed period and history of mild spotting PV. A urine pregnancy test done at home shows 2 lines. All are possible diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Complete Abortion

 

  • Complete Abortion will present with heavy bleeding with the passage of fleshy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Placental sign or implantation bleeding will have minimal bleeding
  • Threatened and missed abortion will only have spotting or minimal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Spontaneous Abortion

 

 

Ref: Page No: 159 DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Anti – D prophylaxis should be given following delivery.
Anti -D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.
Anti-D prophylaxis is not required.

questions.text: A 34-year primigravida presents at 34 weeks with mild spotting. She is not in labor and the ultrasound shows the placenta in the upper segment. On evaluation, her blood group is B -negative and her husband is Rh positive. What is true regarding Anti – D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

(Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

 

  • Prophylaxis:
    • Anti D (300 mcg IM) given at 28 weeks (If ICT is negative)
    • Repeated within 72 h after delivery if baby is Rh positive
    • 300 mcg neutralizes 30 ml of fetal blood (15 ml of fetal red cells)
    • Avoid past dates; Avoid methylergometrine
    • Delivery is the cause of 90% of feto maternal haemorrhage
    • Also given after inciting events (When feto maternal haemorrhage can happen)
    • Dose: 50 mcg < 12 weeks and 300 mcg if > 12 weeks

 

Inciting events:

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given following delivery: While it's true that Anti-D is routinely given postpartum, this option overlooks the immediate need due to the current bleeding episode.

 

Option B. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible only if she has not received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks: This option is not accurate because the need for Anti-D prophylaxis in the event of antepartum bleeding is independent of whether she received prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Option C. Anti-D prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible even if she has received Anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks (Correct Answer): This is the correct approach. The woman should receive Anti-D prophylaxis as soon as possible following the bleeding episode, regardless of her having received a routine dose at 28 weeks. Each episode of potential fetal-maternal hemorrhage, such as bleeding in pregnancy, warrants a dose of Anti-D.

 

Option D. Anti-D prophylaxis is not required: This is incorrect. Given the woman’s Rh-negative status and the occurrence of antepartum bleeding, Anti-D prophylaxis is necessary.

 

Educational Objective: Rh-negative pregnant women should receive Anti-D prophylaxis following any antepartum bleeding event to prevent Rh sensitization, regardless of prior prophylaxis at 28 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 305, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition)

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the OPD with excess facial hair for 6 months and delayed menstrual cycles. On evaluation, levels of free testosterone are increased. An ultrasound reveals normal uterus and normal ovaries on USG. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism.

  • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose  PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present:

    1. Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 20 amenorrhea, and infertility)

    2. Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism)

    3. 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).

 

 

USG appearance of polycystic ovaries

 

  • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS

 

let's consider the other options:

 

Option. A. Adrenal Hyperplasia: Adrenal hyperplasia, particularly congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities, due to elevated androgens. However, it is usually diagnosed earlier in life and often has other associated adrenal hormone abnormalities.

 

Option. B. Idiopathic Hirsutism: Idiopathic hirsutism refers to hirsutism (excess hair growth) in the absence of any identifiable hormonal imbalance or ovarian/adrenal gland disorder. Given the increased free testosterone levels in this patient, idiopathic hirsutism is less likely.

 

Option. D. Testosterone Secreting Tumor: While a testosterone-secreting tumor can cause increased androgen levels and symptoms like hirsutism, these tumors are rare. The more common presentation of such tumors would include rapid onset of symptoms and markedly elevated testosterone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is the most likely diagnosis in a young woman presenting with hirsutism, menstrual irregularities, and elevated free testosterone levels. The diagnosis of PCOS is based on a combination of clinical, biochemical, and ultrasound findings, and it is important to consider this condition in women with such symptoms.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Speroffs Clinical Gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: A 26y old gives a history of two 1st trimester abortions following delivery of a preterm baby at 30 weeks due to severe preeclampsia. She is anxious and wants to be evaluated preconceptionally. Which of the following investigation will you advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lupus anticoagulant

 

Based on the history, Antiphospholipid antibody Syndrome is probable. Hence the investigation of choice is Lupus Anticoagulant.

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome

 

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

 

Clinical Criteria

 

Obstetric

 

  • One or more unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus > 10 weeks

 

OR

 

  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

 

OR

 

  • 3 or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

 

Vascular

 

  • 1 or more episode of arterial/venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

 

Lab Criteria (Present on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart)

 

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant

 

OR

 

  • Medium to high titers of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin Antibodies

 

OR

 

  • Anti β2 glycoprotein – IgG or IgM Antibody

 

Educational Objective:

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

choices.text: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers
There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy
About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

Explanation

  • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis
    • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
    • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
    • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
    • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

In Placenta Accrete Syndromes, the abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer

 

Ref: Page no 1974, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: All the following have been implicated in spontaneous abortion except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subclinical hyperthyroidism

 

Subclinical hyperthyroidism is not implicated in causing spontaneous abortion

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Ref: Page no. 347, Williams 25th edition

choices.text: Elective LSCS at 34 weeks
Elective LSCS at 37 weeks
Induction of labor at 37 weeks
Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.text: A 36-year lady was diagnosed to have monoamniotic monochorionic twins. She is now 33 weeks. What should be the plan of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective LSCS at 34 weeks

 

Monoamniotic Twin Pregnancy

 

  • Absence of an inter-twin dividing membrane
  • Risk of Cord entanglement as both the twins are in the same amniotic cavity
  • Management: Elective LSCS after 34 weeks after corticosteroids
  • This is done to prevent sudden IUD of one or both twins due to cord entanglement

 

Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Elective LSCS at 34 weeks (Correct Answer): Monoamniotic monochorionic twins are at high risk for complications such as cord entanglement and compression. Elective Cesarean section (LSCS) around 34 weeks is often recommended to reduce these risks while balancing the complications of prematurity.

 

Option B. Elective LSCS at 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks in a monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancy might increase the risk of intrauterine fetal demise due to cord complications. Earlier delivery is generally preferred.

 

Option C. Induction of Labor at 37   weeks: Induction of labor is typically avoided in monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies due to the high risk of cord entanglement and compression during vaginal delivery.

 

Option D. Wait for Spontaneous Onset of Labor: Waiting for spontaneous labor is not recommended in monoamniotic monochorionic twins due to the increased risks associated with prolonging the pregnancy, including the potential for cord accidents.

 

Educational Objective: In monoamniotic monochorionic twin pregnancies, where twins share both the amniotic sac and the placenta, the risks of cord entanglement and compression are significant. To minimize these risks, elective Cesarean section around 34 weeks gestation is often the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: page no 873, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Arrange for cordocentesis and consider Intra uterine transfusion if PCV < 30%
Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver.
Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry
Repeat a PSV of the MCA after  2 weeks

questions.text: A 25-year G3P2 presented to the Antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. Her blood group is B neg and her partners blood group is B +. Indirect Coombs test revealed high titers and an MCA revealed an increased diastolic flow > 1.5 MoM with a normal peak systolic velocity. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks

 

  • In the scenario given, it is mentioned that the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal.
  • The patient needs to be followed up.
  • Only when the PSV> 1.5 MoM; should a cordocentesis be done

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Arrange for cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if PCV < 30%: Cordocentesis is a procedure to obtain fetal blood and assess hematocrit (PCV). Intrauterine transfusion is considered if fetal anemia is confirmed. However, this step might be premature if only the diastolic flow in the MCA is increased, and the peak systolic velocity (PSV) is normal. Cordocentesis carries risks and is typically considered when there's clear evidence of fetal anemia.

 

Option B. Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver: Administering Betamethasone and planning for delivery would be considered if there's evidence of significant fetal compromise and the pregnancy is at a stage where delivery is viable. At 28 weeks, unless there is urgent evidence of severe fetal distress, immediate delivery is not typically the first choice.

 

Option C. Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry: Amniotic fluid spectrophotometry is used to measure bilirubin levels, which can indicate fetal hemolysis. However, with the advent of non-invasive methods like MCA Doppler, its use has decreased

 

Option D. Repeat a PSV of the MCA after 2 weeks (Correct Answer): Since the peak systolic velocity of the MCA is normal, indicating no immediate severe fetal anemia, monitoring with a repeat MCA Doppler in 2 weeks is a prudent approach.

 

Educational Objective: In cases of suspected fetal anemia due to Rh incompatibility, monitoring with repeated MCA Doppler studies is crucial, especially when initial findings are borderline or inconclusive. This approach allows for close surveillance of the fetus and helps in deciding the appropriate time for interventions like cordocentesis or intrauterine transfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 303, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: All are ultrasound signs of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lemon sign

In Suspected unruptured ectopic pregnancy: Trans-vaginal Sonography (TVS) will reveal

    • An absent intra-uterine pregnancy
    • The presence of a pseudo-sac in the uterine cavity
    • The presence of an adnexal mass separate from the ovary
      • Hyperechoic ring surrounding an anechoic sac- seen in 20% (bagel sign/tubal ring sign)
      • Inhomogeneous mass – 60% (blob sign)
      • Obvious gestational sac with a fetal pole – 13%
    • On color doppler: “Ring of fire” seen. (D/d – Corpus luteal cyst)

 

*Lemon sign is seen in a fetus with spina bifida

 

Ref: page no 375, William Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 35y asthmatic was induced for FGR at 37 weeks. She is now in the 3rd stage of labor having delivered a 2 kg female baby. Following delivery of the placenta, she starts bleeding profusely. The uterus is atonic. Which uterotone will NOT be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carboprost.

 

  • Carboprost (or Prostadin) is a15-methyl analogues of PGF2
  • It is Contraindicated in asthmatic women as it causes bronchoconstriction
  • Other drugs that are given for atonic PPH 
  1. Oxytocin
  2. Methylergometrine
  3. Oxytocin + Ergometrine (Syntometrine)
  4. Misoprostol

 

 

Ref: Page no 363, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: The highest risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 12-20 weeks

  • Congenital Varicella Syndrome is characterized by
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is diagnosed to have a twin pregnancy on her first trimester ultrasound. The following image is seen on ultrasound. What is chorionicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dichorionic diamniotic

 

  • Determination of chorionicity:
    • Determined best by ultrasound in the 1st trimester (8- 10 weeks)
    • Twin peak sign (Lambda sign) – Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins
    • Inverted T sign – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • No intervening membrane in Monochorionic Monoamniotic Twins

 

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Monochorionic Diamniotic: This type involves one shared chorion (outer membrane) and two separate amnions (inner membranes) for each twin. On ultrasound, this is indicated by a thin dividing membrane (inverted T sign).

 

Option B. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: Twins share the same chorion and amnion. This is a rare and high-risk situation as it can lead to complications like cord entanglement. On ultrasound, there would be no membrane separating the twins.

 

Option C. Dichorionic Diamniotic (Likely Answer): Each twin has its own chorion and amnion. This is the most common type of twin pregnancy and is considered the lowest risk. On ultrasound, this is indicated by the presence of a 'twin peak' or 'lambda' sign, where a wedge of placental tissue extends between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

 

Option D. Conjoined Twins: This is an extremely rare condition where the twins are physically connected to each other. It is usually identifiable on ultrasound by the continuous body structure shared between the twins.

 

Educational Objective: The chorionicity in twin pregnancies is determined through ultrasound features, with dichorionic diamniotic twins having separate chorionic and amniotic sacs for each twin, often indicated by the presence of the 'twin peak' or 'lambda' sign

 

Ref: page no 868-869, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
